This course was very educational and taught me a lot about the big 3 diseases, as well as their history and biology. Professor Parikh brought these topics to life, and his medical experience was a big benefit for the class.
Overall, I think this was a good course. I especially appreciated the opportunity to hear about some of the clinical presentations of the diseases.

Fascinating material- one of the more science-heavy classes I've taken at YSPH, but it all seemed necessary to truly get a handle on the epidemiology, prevention, and treatment of each of the Big3. I really enjoyed each lecture, which were nicely supplemented by a reasonable amount of reading. 

 I was a bit confused as to the ordering of the lectures (I think this may have perhaps been due to guest lecture scheduling). I think it would have worked better to do the introductory lecture, all of the HIV lectures, all of the malaria lectures, and then all of the TB lectures, if possible.

 The homework assignments were time consuming but were good in that they required comprehension and synthesis of the material. 

I felt that the final project was a bit anti-climactic given the engaging and interesting material throughout the semester. Maybe having each group do a case study would be more relevant?

I enjoyed the material covered in this course, and think such a course is critical for the EMD curriculum. Strengths include the range of topics covered and Dr. Parikh's easygoing lecture style. Sometimes, though, the course felt slightly unstructured in that I was never quite sure what information/themes from the lectures/power points were the most important. The quizzes in particular felt unpredictable to me, but the homework assignments helped me figure out what to focus on a bit. I particularly enjoyed the focus on epidemics throughout different regions in Africa, and I would have liked to learn a little more about field techniques used to gather data, monitor disease outbreaks, and treat patients in difficult-to-reach settings.

Too many assessments. Did not find quizzes useful for learning. Great assignments and interesting final assignment. 

Very interesting course would recommend if student is interested in the topics.

Strengths - very straightforward, content-driven class, amazing instructor, not that much work

Weaknesses - for the most part, lectures are just Sunil reading off slides, which can get boring, the material also repeats itself a bit

This course has much potential, but is not executed properly. I can't say I learned new things about the three diseases. Most of the course was just statistics being rattled off. Additionally, the course was incredibly focused on malaria (5 weeks of malaria, 3 of HIV, and 3 of TB). However, we often didn't finish the lecture slides so what was only supposed to be 5 lectures on malaria ended up being much more. I wish there were more examples of cases, stories, or anecdotes discussed, rather than just statistics about the diseases.

The syllabus was changed at least 10 times with due dates being shifted quite often. I found it hard to keep up with the assignments/when they were due. The assignment due dates were pushed back because we didn't finish the lectures, but sometimes I didn't have time to wait for the topic to be discussed in lecture, so I had to do the assignment blindly, which resulted in lower grades. The quizzes (a new addition this year) were supposed to be on the "nuts and bolts" of the diseases. Instead, they involved incredibly minute details barely discussed in lecture. They ended up needing to be drastically curved because everyone would have failed. I felt like I did not get much out of the course.

Great course, learned so much about such a wide, contemporary problem facing the world. Would liked to have a better thread connecting the Big 3 diseases and understanding why they are considered the Big 3, which seemingly implies that other diseases are less impactful. However, given that it is a term that exists outside of just Professor Parikh's syllabus, the course did a great job of tackling the problems it said it would explicitly.
Really interesting class, but the assessment system needs to be improved. (Homeworks were long and quizzes were a little too specific.)

The course was very comprehensive, which is a rare find at YSPH. This year, the quizzes were new and they were extremely specific and challenging. I would recommend broader scope quizzes or clarify expectations on what students should know to successfully complete quizzes.

Professor Parikh was great at presenting the information in a fascinating and engaging way, and helped us think critically about different studies and interventions, as well as historical precedents. His quizzes were extremely challenging, but they forced us to think more critically about the material. He was a wonderful professor and I really enjoyed the class.
Very nice, some weaknesses in presenting material in lecture however.  The slides are usually just either epi data or maps of Africa.

I think Dr. Parikh explains things well and takes his time to go over the concepts. I think his time management could be better so that we can get through all of his slides more. Overall, he is a good professor.
Incredible. Intelligent. Thoughtful. Helpful. Funny.
Sunil is very knowledgeable and passionate about this subject area! He's also easy going and fair. A great professor overall!

Although the course was a bit unstructured in some ways, I really enjoyed Dr. Parikh. He is extremely easy to talk to, receptive to questions and feedback, and is clearly passionate and knowledgeable.
Wonderful. Knowledgeable. Engaging.
Very smart man, receptive to student feedback.
Sunil is a fantastic instructor! He is very responsive to the class and individual needs and desires.
Very easy to speak to and learn from, engaging lecturer, and really cool guy.

Good professor with a very interesting subject. Only recommendation would be to shorten homeworks and give a bit more guidance going into the quizzes. I would still recommend offering the course again.
Kind but very disorganized course.
Do not take this course unless your focus at YSPH is on one of the Big 3 or work in Africa. No real issues with the course, just a bit boring overall.
I would recommend this course.
I would recommend this class, even if you aren't an EMD student. I was fascinated by each lecture
This course examines the global history of TB, malaria, and HIV, and also focuses on treatments and epidemiology. I would recommend the course to anyone interested.
This is a good class - not too bad work-wise, the content is not hard to grasp, the teacher is great. I would 100% take it again.
Perhaps for a non-EMD student, this may be useful. However, I didn't feel that I learned much more than I had already learned in previous coursework.
Very necessary introduction to massive problems facing Global Health today.
I would recommend the course.
